quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 13 Quiz 5
quiz.subtitle: 13.5: Radioactive Dating
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Carbon-14 dating, Uranium-Lead dating, and applications

questions.question: Which isotope is most commonly used to date once-living organic materials up to approximately 50,000 years old?
questions.explanation: Carbon-14 is incorporated into living tissues and begins to decay once the organism dies, making it a clock for organic remains.

questions.question: What is the primary source of Carbon-14 in the Earth's atmosphere?
options: Natural decay of Uranium in the soil
questions.explanation: High-energy neutrons from cosmic rays collide with nitrogen atoms in the upper atmosphere to produce C-14.

questions.question: Why is Carbon-14 dating ineffective for objects that are millions of years old?
options: The half-life of C-14 is too short (5,730 years).
Carbon does not exist in very old rocks.
C-14 only works on metallic objects.
The decay constant of C-14 changes over long periods.
questions.explanation: After about 10 half-lives (~50,000 to 60,000 years), the amount of C-14 remaining is too small to measure accurately.

questions.question: Which isotope pair is typically used to determine the age of the Earth and very ancient rocks?
questions.explanation: Uranium-238 has a half-life of 4.5 billion years, making it ideal for geological dating on a planetary scale.

questions.question: In radioactive dating, the 'parent' isotope decays into a stable:
questions.explanation: The ratio of the parent isotope to the daughter isotope is used to calculate the time elapsed since the 'clock' started.

questions.question: What assumption is made when using the Potassium-Argon ($^{40}K/^{40}Ar$) dating method for volcanic rocks?
options: No Argon-40 was present when the rock solidified.
The rock has been underwater for its entire existence.
Argon-40 is a solid at all temperatures.
questions.explanation: Argon is a gas; it is assumed that any pre-existing Argon escaped while the rock was molten, so all Argon found now must come from decay since solidification.

questions.question: If a sample contains 25% of its original Carbon-14, how many half-lives have passed?
Which method would be best for dating a wooden tool found in an archaeological site from 3,000 years ago?
questions.explanation: Wood is organic and the timeframe (3,000 years) is well within the range of Carbon-14's utility.

questions.question: Radioactive dating is possible because the rate of decay is:
options: Constant and unaffected by environmental conditions.
Dependent on the chemical bonds of the atom.
Faster in the vacuum of space.
Proportional to the temperature of the sample.
questions.explanation: Nuclear decay rates are intrinsic to the nucleus and remain constant regardless of heat, pressure, or chemical state.

questions.question: What is the half-life of Carbon-14?
questions.explanation: The standard accepted value for the half-life of C-14 is 5,730 years.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand how isotopes act as geological and archaeological clocks.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You know which isotopes fit specific time scales.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Review the limitations of Carbon-14 dating.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the relationship between half-life and the age of the sample.
